Award.AwardTitle: An Integrated Structural, Petrologic and Isotopic Study of Fabric Evolution in the Ailao Shan-Red River Shear Zone, China
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to establish the history of the crustal rocks in the Red River shear zone that forms an arc-shaped fault that sweeps clock-wise from eastern Tibet across southwestern China and then follows the Red River through Hanoi to the Gulf of Tonkin. This fault accommodated hundreds of km of displacement in the geologically recent past, about 30 million years ago. The hypothesis being tested is that of shear heating. It is possible that the rocks in the fault might be heated by the friction associated with these large displacements. If the rocks in this fault zone had been so heated, then they would become weak and less prone to earthquakes. This NSF project is funding field work to allow structural observations and sample collection in China, as well as laboratory work on samples to detect when the last heating event occurred. This project also involves collaboration with Taiwanese researchers, which adds significant international impact.

More specifically, the rocks in this fault zone are thought by some to have been metamorphosed by shear heating as the Indochina block was extruded past the Yangtze block during the Oligocene-Miocene collision of India with Asia. Some of the evidence for heating comes from the Oligocene to Miocene ages of thermochronometers, especially monazite, muscovite, and K-feldspar. With the interpretation that these ages are all cooling ages, it follows that the rocks experienced temperatures of > 700Â°C between 30 and 20 Ma, and cooled quickly after that. However, it is also possible that these ages may be crystallization ages, in which case the argument for shear heating becomes considerably weaker. We will characterize muscovite and K-feldspar to determine whether those minerals are magmatic or metamorphic. We will then date these minerals using the 40Ar/39Ar age spectrum method. If the results show any ages older than ~30 Ma, then the hypothesis of shear heating can be dismissed as a viable weakening mechanism, at least in these rocks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this project were to identify the processes by which large strike-slip faults deform the crust. The San Andreas Fault in California is one such fault that is rather well known. A very important fault in southeast Asia is the Ailao Shan-Red River Shear Zone that stretches from the Qiangtang province in the Tibetan plateau southeast to Hanoi, Viet Nam (Fig. 1). This fault is thought to have accommodated hundreds of kilometers of strike-slip displacement that allowed the Indochina block to slide SE along SE China. At the surface today sedimentary rocks are found crushed and broken. However, the displacement must have occurred in rocks far below the surface, where temperatures and pressures were much higher.  This is the depth of the seismogenic zone, where crustal earthquakes are generated.

 Four blocks of rocks from the lower crust are exposed along this fault. They preserve some of the textures and structures that were generated at the lower crustal conditions.  We have studies two of these blocks to try to establish how these rocks deformed when they were deeper. We have used mineralogical, chemical and isotopic methods to determine how hot and how deep the rocks were when they were deformed, and when and how fact these rocks were extruded to the surface.

 We have discovered that these rocks were deforming large without major earthquake activity. In fact the rocks were sufficiently hot that most of the strain was accommodated by ductile flow, analogous to glacial flow. We have determined the details of some deformation mechanisms that include dissolution of strong minerals and precipitation of weak minerals. This process is called reaction softening, and this allows the rock to flow without major fracture even as these crustal blocks became cool enough to fracture during their exhumation to the surface. These processes dominate over fracture mechanisms, but still we find evidence for oscillation of strength at the microscopic scale, from brittle fracture of a few grains to ductile flow, especially in weak micaceous minerals.  What is clear is that minerals become smaller, and rocks become layered and foliated (Fig. 2).

 Our studies have shown that these blocks started their journey to the surface about 32 million years ago, and translated in strike-slip fashion for about 20 million years staying in the middle crust, and then came quickly to the surface over the last 5 million years. They may well still be moving up today. Now the erosion rate is approximately keeping pace with rock uplift, so these blocks are not much higher that the surrounding rocks.

 Thus study has involved the cooperative research of several scientists, including faculty at Indiana University, at the China University of Geosciences, Beijing, as well as female faculty from the National Taiwan Normal University. It also involved students from all three of these universities.
